Key Arguments: The legislation will negatively impact free speech by encouraging censorship.
Existing laws already address the harms the bill seeks to prevent.
The bill unfairly targets new media entrants while exempting legacy media and government sources.
Regulating misinformation is futile due to technological advancements that allow circumvention.
The bill could stifle innovation and prevent new media platforms from entering the Australian market.
Notable Quotes: The FSU strongly objects to the passing of the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023 into law, primarily due to the impact it will have upon Free Speech by encouraging censorship and by impeding innovation in the online media space.
This law encourages and promotes censorship by compelling digital platforms to create a means to identify and remove misinformation and disinformation.
By judging truth on the prevailing orthodoxy, digital media platforms will be distorting important public debates.
This Bill places a considerable burden upon new entrants to the media landscape and given the size of the Australian market, many may simply choose not to operate in Australia.
